title: Dover publications serif font
content:
Does anybody know the name of the serif font used by Dover Publications (not the font used on their front covers, the one for the main text of the book). It looks like something from the 1960’s, and has nice old style numerals and small caps. I’ve tried Identifont et al. and they suggest faces that are close, but not quite correct (Bodoni Condensed, Century Oldstyle etc.)

I’ve attached a small excerpt from one of their books (sorry for the quality, it’s a scan).

author: dpm

comments.content:
In your sample the word CONTENTS at the top is a different font (the C has 2 serifs). The main text does look like one of the Century’s (there are many if you use Bitstream’s naming). I cannot see the details clearly enough to use the [Serif Font ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20090607101825/http:/www.bowfinprintworks.com/SerifGuide/serifsearch.php), but with the original maybe you can try it and see what comes up.

- Mike Yanega

Ah, cool. Thanks for that, Monotype Modern looks to be the correct font! I’m actually wanting to use this font in LaTeX to typeset my thesis in, as I prefer this font to CM. Is the lack of scaling in the Monotype official going to be a killer?

Heh, interesting. Yes, the Monotype digital will be impossibly high-contrast (hairline serifs way too thin) at normal text sizes. However, you may not be entirely out of luck. There’s a [second digitization](http://web.archive.org/web/20090607101825/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/modern-extended/) that’s quite a bit more robust. You could use this for text and the Monotype for larger settings, and get fake scaling. However, if you have lots of subscripts or other small type mixed in with the main text, I’d personally find the lack of scaling to be disappointing. I expect it from Times, but not from this font.

Best of luck!

raph, thanks for that. I will have a lot of subscripts and superscripts, so it looks like using MM is out (I’d rather stick with CM in that case).

Stephen Coles, thanks for the link. I’ll take a look at those!
